Database.Title: Knowledge Base Bioinformatics Database
Database.Notes: This document is used to create the central store for the KBase project. The document itself is called the [i]Central Data Model[/i], and a database created from it is called a [i]Central Data Model Instance[/i]. In addition to the Central Store, private CDMI databases can be created, and these are sometimes referred to as [i]Tiny Stores[/i].

Region.name: Chemistry
Region.Notes: The Chemistry region contains data about reactions, compounds, locations, and media conditions.

Region.name: Annotations
Region.Notes: The Annotations region contains feature annotation history, information about functional coupling, and annotation clearinghouse assertions.

Region.name: Models
Region.Notes: The Models region contains data related to metabolic flux models.

Region.name: Expression
Region.Notes: The Expression region contains data related to gene expression and regulation.

Region.name: Alignments
Region.Notes: The Alignments region contains data related to alignments and trees of features and proteins, organized into projects related by roles.

Region.name: Subsystem
Region.Notes: The subsystem region contains data related to subsystems and subsystem spreadsheets

Region.name: GenoPheno
Region.Notes: The Genotype to Phenotype region contains data about the relationship between experimentally determined alleles in a DNA sequence and observed traits for plants.

Region.name: Strain
Region.Notes: The Strain region contains data modeling strains of organisms derived from a parent genome and their relationships.

Region.name: Regulation
Region.Notes: The Regulation region contains data about regulatory networks.

Region.name: Expression_v2
Region.Notes: The expression_v2 contains expression data for various expression experiments (Microarray, RNA-Seq, proteomics, qPCR). It will eventually replace any existing expression schema.

Entity.name: LocationInstance
Entity.Notes: The Location Instance represents a region of a cell (e.g. cell wall, cytoplasm) as it appears in a specific model.

Field.name: index
Field.Notes: number used to distinguish between different instances of the same type of location in a single model. Within a model, any two instances of the same location must have difference compartment index values.

Field.name: label
Field.Notes: description used to differentiate between instances of the same location in a single model

Field.name: pH
Field.Notes: pH of the cell region, which is used to determine compound charge and pH gradient across cell membranes

Field.name: potential
Field.Notes: electrochemical potential of the cell region, which is used to determine the electrochemical gradient across cell membranes

Entity.name: CompoundInstance
Entity.Notes: A Compound Instance represents the occurrence of a particular compound in a location in a model.

Field.name: charge
Field.Notes: computed charge based on the location instance pH and similar constraints

Field.name: formula
Field.Notes: computed chemical formula for this compound based on the location instance pH and similar constraints

Entity.name: Biomass
Entity.Notes: A biomass is a collection of compounds in a specific ratio and in specific compartments that are necessary for a cell to function properly. The prediction of biomasses is key to the functioning of the model. Each biomass belongs to a specific model.

Field.name: mod-date
Field.Notes: last modification date of the biomass data

Field.name: name
Field.Notes: descriptive name for this biomass

Field.name: dna
Field.Notes: portion of a gram of this biomass (expressed as a fraction of 1.0) that is DNA

Field.name: protein
Field.Notes: portion of a gram of this biomass (expressed as a fraction of 1.0) that is protein

Field.name: cell-wall
Field.Notes: portion of a gram of this biomass (expressed as a fraction of 1.0) that is cell wall

Field.name: lipid
Field.Notes: portion of a gram of this biomass (expressed as a fraction of 1.0) that is lipid but is not part of the cell wall

Field.name: cofactor
Field.Notes: portion of a gram of this biomass (expressed as a fraction of 1.0) that function as cofactors

Field.name: energy
Field.Notes: number of ATP molecules hydrolized per gram of this biomass

Entity.name: ReactionInstance
Entity.Notes: A reaction instance describes the specific implementation of a reaction in a model.

Field.name: direction
Field.Notes: reaction directionality (> for forward, < for backward, = for bidirectional) with respect to this model

Field.name: protons
Field.Notes: number of protons produced by this reaction when proceeding in the forward direction. If this is a transport reaction, these protons end up in the reaction instance's main location. If the number is negative, then the protons are consumed by the reaction rather than being produced.

Entity.name: Model
Entity.Notes: A model specifies a relationship between sets of features and reactions in a cell. It is used to simulate cell growth and gene knockouts to validate annotations.

Field.name: mod-date
Field.Notes: date and time of the last change to the model data

Field.name: name
Field.Notes: descriptive name of the model

Field.name: version
Field.Notes: revision number of the model

Field.name: type
Field.Notes: string indicating where the model came from (e.g. single genome, multiple genome, or community model)

Field.name: status
Field.Notes: indicator of whether the model is stable, under construction, or under reconstruction

Field.name: reaction-count
Field.Notes: number of reactions in the model

Field.name: compound-count
Field.Notes: number of compounds in the model

Field.name: annotation-count
Field.Notes: number of features associated with one or more reactions in the model

Entity.name: Source

Field.name: name
Field.Notes: The user-readable name for this source.

Field.name: url
Field.Notes: The URL to a site with information about this source.

Field.name: description
Field.Notes: A short textual description of this source.

Entity.Notes: A source is a user or organization that is permitted to assign its own identifiers or to submit bioinformatic objects to the database.

Entity.name: Role
Entity.Notes: A role describes a biological function that may be fulfilled by a feature. One of the main goals of the database is to assign features to roles. Most roles are effected by the construction of proteins. Some, however, deal with functional regulation and message transmission.

Field.name: hypothetical
Field.Notes: TRUE if a role is hypothetical, else FALSE

Entity.name: Media
Entity.Notes: A media describes the chemical content of the solution in which cells are grown in an experiment or for the purposes of a model. The key is the common media name. The nature of the media is described by its relationship to its constituent compounds.

Field.name: mod-date
Field.Notes: date and time of the last modification to the media's definition

Field.name: name
Field.Notes: descriptive name of the media

Field.name: is-minimal
Field.Notes: TRUE if this is a minimal media, else FALSE

Field.name: source-id
Field.Notes: The ID of the media used by the data source.

Field.name: type
Field.Notes: The general category of the media.

Index.Notes: This index allows the user to search for a media by source ID.

Entity.name: Location
Entity.Notes: A location is a region of the cell where reaction compounds originate from or are transported to (e.g. cell wall, extracellular, cytoplasm).

Field.name: mod-date
Field.Notes: date and time of the last modification to the compartment's definition

Field.name: name
Field.Notes: common name for the location

Field.name: source-id
Field.Notes: ID from the source of this location

Field.name: abbr
Field.Notes: an abbreviation (usually a single letter) for the location.

Entity.name: Compound
Entity.Notes: A compound is a chemical that participates in a reaction. Both ligands and reaction components are treated as compounds.

Field.name: label
Field.Notes: primary name of the compound, for use in displaying reactions

Field.name: abbr
Field.Notes: shortened abbreviation for the compound name

Field.name: source-id
Field.Notes: common modeling ID of this compound

Field.name: ubiquitous
Field.Notes: TRUE if this compound is found in most reactions, else FALSE

Field.name: mod-date
Field.Notes: date and time of the last modification to the compound definition

Field.name: mass
Field.Notes: pH-neutral atomic mass of the compound

Field.name: formula
Field.Notes: a pH-neutral formula for the compound

Field.name: charge
Field.Notes: computed charge of the compound in a pH-neutral solution

Field.name: deltaG
Field.Notes: the pH 7 reference Gibbs free-energy of formation for this compound as calculated by the group contribution method (units are kcal/mol)

Field.name: deltaG-error
Field.Notes: the uncertainty in the [b]deltaG[/b] value (units are kcal/mol)

Index.Notes: This index allows searching for compounds by name.
This index allows retrieval by the common modeling ID.

Entity.name: Reaction
Entity.Notes: A reaction is a chemical process that converts one set of compounds (substrate) to another set (products).

Field.name: mod-date
Field.Notes: date and time of the last modification to this reaction's definition

Field.name: name
Field.Notes: descriptive name of this reaction

Field.name: source-id
Field.Notes: ID of this reaction in the resource from which it was added

Field.name: abbr
Field.Notes: abbreviated name of this reaction

Field.name: direction
Field.Notes: direction of this reaction (> for forward-only, < for backward-only, = for bidirectional)

Field.name: deltaG
Field.Notes: Gibbs free-energy change for the reaction calculated using the group contribution method (units are kcal/mol)

Field.name: deltaG-error
Field.Notes: uncertainty in the [b]deltaG[/b] value (units are kcal/mol)

Field.name: thermodynamic-reversibility
Field.Notes: computed reversibility of this reaction in a pH-neutral environment

Field.name: default-protons
Field.Notes: number of protons absorbed by this reaction in a pH-neutral environment

Field.name: status
Field.Notes: string indicating additional information about this reaction, generally indicating whether the reaction is balanced and/or lumped

Index.Notes: This index allows retrieval by the common modeling ID.

Entity.name: LocalizedCompound
Entity.Notes: This entity represents a compound occurring in a specific location. A reaction always involves localized compounds. If a reaction occurs entirely in a single location, it will frequently only be represented by the cytoplasmic versions of the compounds; however, a transport always uses specifically located compounds.

Entity.name: Complex
Entity.Notes: A complex is a set of chemical reactions that act in concert to effect a role.

Field.name: name
Field.Notes: name of this complex. Not all complexes have names.

Field.name: source-id
Field.Notes: ID of this complex in the source from which it was added.

Field.name: mod-date
Field.Notes: date and time of the last change to this complex's definition

Index.Notes: This index allows retrieval by the common modeling ID.

Entity.name: Diagram
Entity.Notes: A functional diagram describes a network of chemical reactions, often comprising a single subsystem.

Field.name: name
Field.Notes: descriptive name of this diagram

Field.name: content
Field.Notes: content of the diagram, in PNG format

Entity.name: Subsystem
Entity.Notes: A subsystem is a set of functional roles that have been annotated simultaneously (e.g., the roles present in a specific pathway), with an associated subsystem spreadsheet which encodes the fids in each genome that implement the functional roles in the subsystem.

Field.name: version
Field.Notes: version number for the subsystem. This value is incremented each time the subsystem is backed up.

Field.name: curator
Field.Notes: name of the person currently in charge of the subsystem

Field.name: notes
Field.Notes: descriptive notes about the subsystem

Field.name: description
Field.Notes: description of the subsystem's function in the cell

Field.name: usable
Field.Notes: TRUE if this is a usable subsystem, else FALSE. An unusable subsystem is one that is experimental or is of such low quality that it can negatively affect analysis.

Field.name: private
Field.Notes: TRUE if this is a private subsystem, else FALSE. A private subsystem has valid data, but is not considered ready for general distribution.

Field.name: cluster-based
Field.Notes: TRUE if this is a clustering-based subsystem, else FALSE. A clustering-based subsystem is one in which there is functional-coupling evidence that genes belong together, but we do not yet know what they do.

Field.name: experimental
Field.Notes: TRUE if this is an experimental subsystem, else FALSE. An experimental subsystem is designed for investigation and is not yet ready to be used in comparative analysis and annotation.

Entity.name: SubsystemClass
Entity.Notes: Subsystem classes impose a hierarchical organization on the subsystems.

Entity.name: Publication
Entity.Notes: Experimenters attach publications to experiments and protocols. Annotators attach publications to ProteinSequences. The attached publications give an ID (usually a DOI or Pubmed ID), a URL to the paper (when we have it), and a title (when we have it). Pubmed IDs are given unmodified. DOI IDs are prefixed with [b]doi:[/b], e.g. [i]doi:1002385[/i].
Entity.Asides: The criteria we have used to gather protein sequence connections is a bit nonstandard. We have sought to attach publications to ProteinSequences when the publication includes an expert asserting a belief or estimate of function. The paper may not be the original characterization. Further, it may not even discuss a sequence protein (much of the literature is very valuable, but reports work on proteins in strains that have not yet been sequenced). On the other hand, reports of sequencing regions of a chromosome (with no specific assertion of a clear function) should not be attached.

Field.name: title
Field.Notes: title of the article, or (unknown) if the title is not known

Field.name: link
Field.Notes: URL of the article, DOI preferred

Field.name: pubdate
Field.Notes: publication date of the article

Index.Notes: This index provides the ability to search by article title. It should only be used for LIKE-style searches, since the article titles are encoded together with the URLs.

Entity.name: Variant
Entity.Notes: Each subsystem may include the designation of distinct variants. Thus, there may be three closely-related, but distinguishable forms of histidine degradation. Each form would be called a "variant", with an associated code, and all genomes implementing a specific variant can easily be accessed. The ID is an MD5 of the subsystem name followed by the variant code.
Entity.Asides: The variant code is generally a number with zero or more decimal points, similar to what it done with software version numbers or legal outline numbers.

Field.name: role-rule
Field.Notes: a space-delimited list of role IDs, in alphabetical order, that represents a possible list of non-auxiliary roles applicable to this variant. The roles are identified by their abbreviations. A variant may have multiple role rules.

Field.name: code
Field.Notes: the variant code all by itself

Field.name: type
Field.Notes: variant type indicating the quality of the subsystem support. A type of "vacant" means that the subsystem does not appear to be implemented by the variant. A type of "incomplete" means that the subsystem appears to be missing many reactions. In all other cases, the type is "normal".

Field.name: comment
Field.Notes: commentary text about the variant

Entity.name: ProteinSequence
Entity.Notes: We use the concept of ProteinSequence as an amino acid string with an associated MD5 value. It is easy to access the set of Features that relate to a ProteinSequence. While function is still associated with Features (and may be for some time), publications are associated with ProteinSequences (and the inferred impact on Features is through the relationship connecting ProteinSequences to Features).

Field.name: sequence
Field.Notes: The sequence contains the letters corresponding to the protein's amino acids.

Entity.name: Family
Entity.Notes:
The Kbase will support the maintenance of protein families (as sets of Features with associated translations). We are initially only supporting the notion of a family as composed of a set of isofunctional homologs. That is, the families we initially support should be thought of as containing protein-encoding genes whose associated sequences all implement the same function (we do understand that the notion of "function" is somewhat ambiguous, so let us sweep this under the rug by calling a functional role a "primitive concept").
We currently support families in which the members are protein sequences as well. Identical protein sequences as products of translating distinct genes may or may not have identical functions. This may be justified, since in a very, very, very few cases identical proteins do, in fact, have distinct functions.

Field.name: type
Field.Notes: type of protein family (e.g. FIGfam, equivalog)

Field.name: release
Field.Notes: release number / subtype of protein family

Field.name: family-function
Field.Notes: optional free-form description of the family. For function-based families, this would be the functional role for the family members.

Field.name: alignment
Field.Notes: FASTA-formatted alignment of the family's protein sequences

Index.Notes: This index allows the user to find all families of a given type (e.g. all FIGfams).

Entity.name: SSRow
Entity.Notes: An SSRow (that is, a row in a subsystem spreadsheet) represents a collection of functional roles present in the Features of a single Genome. The roles are part of a designated subsystem, and the features associated with each role are included in the row. That is, a row amounts to an instance of a subsystem as it exists in a specific, designated genome.
Entity.Asides: It is possible for a single subsystem to occur multiple times in a particular genome. If that is the case, then the subsystem will have a molecular machine for each occurrence. The region string used in forming the key insures that each row has a unique ID.

Field.name: curated
Field.Notes: This flag is TRUE if the assignment of the molecular machine has been curated, and FALSE if it was made by an automated program.

Field.name: region
Field.Notes: Region in the genome for which the row is relevant. Normally, this is an empty string, indicating that the machine covers the whole genome. If a subsystem has multiple rows for a genome, this contains a location string describing the region occupied by this particular row.

Entity.name: Pairing
Entity.Notes: A pairing indicates that two features are found close together in a genome. Not all possible pairings are stored in the database; only those that are considered for some reason to be significant for annotation purposes.The key of the pairing is the concatenation of the feature IDs in alphabetical order with an intervening colon.
Entity.Asides: Theoretically, the pairing is unordered: (A,B) and (B,A) are the same pairing. It is frequently the case, however, that we need to refer to the "first" or "second" protein in the pairing. When this happens, the first one is always the protein with the alphabetically lesser key. The IsInPair relationship automatically shows the proteins in this order.

Entity.name: Genome
Entity.Notes: The Kbase houses a large and growing set of genomes. We often have multiple genomes that have identical DNA. These usually have distinct gene calls and annotations, but not always. We consider the Kbase to be a framework for managing hundreds of thousands of genomes and offering the tools needed to support compartive analysis on large sets of genomes, some of which are virtually identical.
Entity.Asides: Each genome has an MD5 value computed from the DNA that is associated with the genome. Hence, it is easy to recognize when you have identical genomes, perhaps annotated by distinct groups.

Field.name: pegs
Field.Notes: Number of protein encoding genes for this genome.

Field.name: rnas
Field.Notes: Number of RNA features found for this organism.

Field.name: scientific-name
Field.Notes: Source name given in the genome source file. Normally, the name includes Genus/Species/Strain. May be different than the names from other sources or from the unifying name in the TaxonomicGrouping.

Field.name: complete
Field.Notes: TRUE if the genome sequence is complete, else FALSE. Complete is defined as having enough information from the source that a meaningful analysis can be performed.

Field.name: prokaryotic
Field.Notes: TRUE if this is a prokaryotic genome sequence, else FALSE

Field.name: dna-size
Field.Notes: Number of base pairs in the genome sequence.

Field.name: contigs
Field.Notes: Number of contigs for this genome sequence.

Field.name: domain
Field.Notes: Domain for this organism (Archaea, Bacteria, Eukaryota, Virus, Plasmid, or Environmental Sample).

Field.name: genetic-code
Field.Notes: Genetic code number used for protein translation on most of this genome sequence's contigs.

Field.name: gc-content
Field.Notes: Percent GC content present in the genome sequence's DNA.

Field.name: phenotype
Field.Notes: zero or more strings describing phenotypic information about this genome sequence

Field.name: md5
Field.Notes: MD5 identifier describing the genome's DNA sequence

Field.name: source-id
Field.Notes: identifier assigned to this genome by the original source

Index.Notes: This index allows the applications to find all genome sequences in lexical order by name.
This index allows the applications to find all genomes with the same genome sequence.
This index allows the applications to find all genomes by the genome ID from the core (source) database.

Entity.name: CodonUsage
Entity.Notes: This entity contains information about the codon usage frequency in a particular genome with respect to a particular type of analysis (e.g. high-expression genes, modal, mean, etc.).

Field.name: frequencies
Field.Notes: A packed-string representation of the codon usage frequencies. These are not global frequencies, but rather frequenicy of use relative to other codons that produce the same amino acid.

Field.name: genetic-code
Field.Notes: Genetic code used for these codons.

Field.name: type
Field.Notes: Type of frequency analysis: average, modal, high-expression, or non-native.

Field.name: subtype
Field.Notes: Specific nature of the codon usage with respect to the given type, generally indicative of how the frequencies were computed.

Entity.name: Annotation
Entity.Notes: An annotation is a comment attached to a feature. Annotations are used to track the history of a feature's functional assignments and any related issues. The key is the feature ID followed by a colon and a complemented ten-digit sequence number.
Entity.Asides: The complemented sequence number causes the annotations to sort with the most recent one first.

Field.name: annotator
Field.Notes: name of the annotator who made the comment

Field.name: comment
Field.Notes: text of the annotation

Field.name: annotation-time
Field.Notes: date and time at which the annotation was made

Entity.name: Contig
Entity.Notes: A contig is thought of as composing a part of the DNA associated with a specific genome. It is represented as an ID (including the genome ID) and a ContigSequence. We do not think of strings of DNA from, say, a metgenomic sample as "contigs", since there is no associated genome (these would be considered ContigSequences). This use of the term "ContigSequence", rather than just "DNA sequence", may turn out to be a bad idea. For now, you should just realize that a Contig has an associated genome, but a ContigSequence does not.

Field.name: source-id
Field.Notes: ID of this contig from the core (source) database

Index.Notes: This index allows you to find a contig by its ID from the core (source) database.

Entity.name: ContigSequence
Entity.Notes: ContigSequences are strings of DNA. Contigs have an associated genome, but ContigSequences do not. We can think of random samples of DNA as a set of ContigSequences. There are no length constraints imposed on ContigSequences -- they can be either very short or very long. The basic unit of data that is moved to/from the database is the ContigChunk, from which ContigSequences are formed. The key of a ContigSequence is the sequence's MD5 identifier.

Field.name: length
Field.Notes: number of base pairs in the contig

Entity.name: ContigChunk
Entity.Notes: ContigChunks are strings of DNA thought of as being a string in a 4-character alphabet with an associated ID. We allow a broader alphabet that includes U (for RNA) and the standard ambiguity characters.
Entity.Asides:
The notion of ContigChunk was introduced to avoid transferring/manipulating huge contigs to access small substrings. A ContigSequence is formed by concatenating a set of one or more ContigChunks. Thus, ContigChunks are the basic units moved from the database to memory. Their existence should be hidden from users in most circumstances (users are expected to request substrings of ContigSequences, and the Kbase software locates the appropriate ContigChunks).
The maximum length of a chunk is one million bases. The key is the contigID followed by a 7-digit ordinal number. So, the first sequence will have an ordinal of 0000000 and contain the base pairs from position 1 to position 1,000,000, the second will have an ordinal of 0000001 and contain the pairs from position 1,000,001 to 2,000,000, and so forth. This will allow us to store 10 trillion base pairs per contig.

Field.name: sequence
Field.Notes: base pairs that make up this sequence

Entity.name: EcNumber
Entity.Notes: EC numbers are assigned by the Enzyme Commission, and consist of four numbers separated by periods, each indicating a successively smaller cateogry of enzymes.

Field.name: obsolete
Field.Notes: This boolean indicates when an EC number is obsolete.

Field.name: replacedby
Field.Notes: When an obsolete EC number is replaced with another EC number, this string will hold the name of the replacement EC number.

Entity.name: SSCell
Entity.Notes: An SSCell (SpreadSheet Cell) represents a role as it occurs in a subsystem spreadsheet row. The key is a colon-delimited triple containing an MD5 hash of the subsystem ID followed by a genome ID (with optional region string) and a role abbreviation.
Entity.Asides: Features in the subsystem are assigned directly to the machine role.

Entity.name: OTU
Entity.Notes: An OTU (Organism Taxonomic Unit) is a named group of related genomes.
Entity.Asides: Each OTU consists of genomes that use highly similar ribosomal small subunits. Two genomes are in the same set if they have a similarity of 97% or greater in subunits of length 1000 or more.

Entity.name: PairSet
Entity.Notes: A PairSet is a precomputed set of pairs of genes. The pairs in a set occur close to one another of the chromosome. We believe that all of the first members of the pairs correspond to one another (are quite similar), as do all of the second members of the pairs. These pairs (from prokaryotic genomes) offer one of the most powerful clues relating to uncharacterized genes/proteins.
Entity.Asides: The pairings for a particular evidence set will contain protein sequences that are significantly similar. In other words, if (A,B) and (X,Y) are both pairings in a single evidence set, then (A =~ X) and (B =~ Y) or (A =~ Y) and (B =~ X), depending on the value of the "inverted" attribute of the IsDeterminedBy relationship. Essentially, a pairing in its own right is unordered. If (A,B) is a pair, then so is (B,A). However, the evidence set maintains a correspondence between its pairs that _is_ ordered, because the constituent pairs must match. The direction in which a pair matches others in the set is an attribute of the relationship from the pairs to the sets.

Field.name: score
Field.Notes: Score for this evidence set. The score indicates the number of significantly different genomes represented by the pairings.

Entity.name: Feature
Entity.Notes: A feature (sometimes also called a gene) is a part of a genome that is of special interest. Features may be spread across multiple DNA sequences (contigs) of a genome, but never across more than one genome. Each feature in the database has a unique ID that functions as its ID in this table. Normally a Feature is just a single contigous region on a contig. Features have types, and an appropriate choice of available types allows the support of protein-encoding genes, exons, RNA genes, binding sites, pathogenicity islands, or whatever.

Field.name: feature-type
Field.Notes: Code indicating the type of this feature. Among the codes currently supported are "peg" for a protein encoding gene, "bs" for a binding site, "opr" for an operon, and so forth.

Field.name: source-id
Field.Notes: ID for this feature in its original source (core) database

Field.name: sequence-length
Field.Notes: Number of base pairs in this feature.

Field.name: function
Field.Notes: Functional assignment for this feature. This will often indicate the feature's functional role or roles, and may also have comments.
Field.Asides: It will frequently be the case that a feature is assigned to a single role, and it is identical to the function. In some cases, a feature will have multiple roles, and all of them will be listed in the function field. In addition, the function may have comment text at the end.

Field.name: alias
Field.Notes: alternative identifier for the feature. These are highly unstructured, and frequently non-unique.

Index.Notes: This index is used to find features by their original database ID.
This index is used to find features by their alias identifiers.

Entity.name: Scenario
Entity.Notes: A scenario is a partial instance of a subsystem with a defined set of reactions. Each scenario converts input compounds to output compounds using reactions. The scenario may use all of the reactions controlled by a subsystem or only some, and may also incorporate additional reactions. Because scenario names are not unique, the actual scenario ID is a number.

Field.name: common-name
Field.Notes: Common name of the scenario. The name, rather than the ID number, is usually displayed everywhere.

Index.Notes: This index allows the user to search for a scenario by name.

Entity.name: TaxonomicGrouping
Entity.Notes: We associate with most genomes a "taxonomy" based on the NCBI taxonomy. This includes, for each genome, a list of ever larger taxonomic groups. The groups are stored as instances of this entity, and chained together by the IsGroupFor relationship.

Field.name: domain
Field.Notes: TRUE if this is a domain grouping, else FALSE.

Field.name: hidden
Field.Notes: TRUE if this is a hidden grouping, else FALSE. Hidden groupings are not typically shown in a lineage list.

Field.name: scientific-name
Field.Notes: Primary scientific name for this grouping. This is the name used when displaying a taxonomy.

Field.name: type
Field.Notes: Type of group, as specified in the NCBI taxonomy database.

Field.name: alias
Field.Notes: Alternate name for this grouping. A grouping may have many alternate names. The scientific name should also be in this list.

Index.Notes: This index allows the user to find a particular taxonomic grouping by name. Because the scientifc name is also an alias, there is no index on scientific name.

Entity.name: ProbeSet
Entity.Notes: A probe set is a device containing multiple probe sequences for use in gene expression experiments.

Entity.name: Experiment
Entity.Notes: An experiment is a combination of conditions for which gene expression information is desired. The result of the experiment is a set of expression levels for features under the given conditions.

Field.name: source
Field.Notes: Publication or lab relevant to this experiment.

Entity.name: StudyExperiment
Entity.Notes: An Experiment is a collection of observational units with one originator that are part of a specific study. An experiment may be conducted at more than one location and in more than one season or year.

Field.name: source-name
Field.Notes: Name/ID by which the experiment is known at the source.

Field.name: design
Field.Notes: Design of the experiment including the numbers and types of observational units, traits, replicates, sampling plan, and analysis that are planned.

Field.name: originator
Field.Notes: Name of the individual or program that are the originators of the experiment.

Entity.name: Locality
Entity.Notes: A locality is a geographic location.

Field.name: source-name
Field.Notes: Name or description of the location used as a collection site.

Field.name: city
Field.Notes: City of the collecting site.

Field.name: state
Field.Notes: State or province of the collecting site.

Field.name: country
Field.Notes: Country of the collecting site.

Field.name: origcty
Field.Notes: 3-letter ISO 3166-1 extended country code for the country of origin.

Field.name: elevation
Field.Notes: Elevation of the collecting site, expressed in meters above sea level. Negative values are allowed.

Field.name: latitude
Field.Notes: Latitude of the collecting site, recorded as a decimal number. North latitudes are positive values and south latitudes are negative numbers.

Field.name: longitude
Field.Notes: Longitude of the collecting site, recorded as a decimal number. West longitudes are positive values and east longitudes are negative numbers.

Field.name: lo-accession
Field.Notes: gazeteer ontology term ID

Entity.name: ObservationalUnit
Entity.Notes: An ObservationalUnit is an individual plant that 1) is part of an experiment or study, 2) has measured traits, and 3) is assayed for the purpose of determining alleles.
Entity.Asides: It is assumed that each observational unit belongs to only one experiment. If the plant later becomes part of another experiment, a new observational unit record and ID will be created.

Field.name: source-name
Field.Notes: Name/ID by which the observational unit may be known by the originator and is used in queries.

Field.name: source-name2
Field.Notes: Secondary name/ID by which the observational unit may be known and is queried.

Field.name: plant-id
Field.Notes: ID of the plant that was tested to produce this observational unit. Observational units with the same plant ID are different assays of a single physical organism.

Entity.name: Trait
Entity.Notes: A Trait is a phenotypic quality that can be measured or observed for an observational unit. Examples include height, sugar content, color, or cold tolerance.
Entity.Asides: It is assumed that each observational unit belongs to only one experiment. If the plant later becomes part of another experiment, a new observational unit record and ID will be created.

Field.name: trait-name
Field.Notes: Text name or description of the trait

Field.name: unit-of-measure
Field.Notes: The units of measure used when determining this trait. If multiple units of measure are applicable, each has its own row in the database.

Field.name: TO-ID
Field.Notes: Trait Ontology term ID (http://www.gramene.org/plant-ontology/)

Field.name: protocol
Field.Notes: A thorough description of how the trait was collected, and if a rating, the minimum and maximum values

Entity.name: Assay
Entity.Notes: An assay is an experimental design for determining alleles at specific chromosome positions.

Field.name: source-id
Field.Notes: identifier for this assay in the original (source) database

Field.name: assay-type
Field.Notes: Text description of the type of assay (e.g., SNP, length, sequence, categorical, array, short read, SSR marker, AFLP marker)

Field.name: assay-type-id
Field.Notes: source ID associated with the assay type (informational)

Entity.name: AlleleFrequency
Entity.Notes: An allele frequency represents a summary of the major and minor allele frequencies for a position on a chromosome.

Field.name: source-id
Field.Notes: identifier for this allele in the original (source) database

Field.name: position
Field.Notes: Specific position on the contig where the allele occurs

Field.name: minor-AF
Field.Notes: Minor allele frequency. Floating point number from 0.0 to 0.5.

Field.name: minor-allele
Field.Notes: Text letter representation of the minor allele. Valid values are A, C, G, and T.

Field.name: major-AF
Field.Notes: Major allele frequency. Floating point number less than or equal to 1.0.

Field.name: major-allele
Field.Notes: Text letter representation of the major allele. Valid values are A, C, G, and T.

Field.name: obs-unit-count
Field.Notes: Number of observational units used to compute the allele frequencies. Indicates the quality of the analysis.

Entity.name: Attribute
Entity.Notes: An attribute describes a category of condition or characteristic for an experiment. The goals of the experiment can be inferred from its values for all the attributes of interest.

Field.name: description
Field.Notes: Descriptive text indicating the nature and use of this attribute.

Entity.name: CoregulatedSet
Entity.Notes: We need to represent sets of genes that are coregulated via some regulatory mechanism. In particular, we wish to represent genes that are coregulated using transcription binding sites and corresponding transcription regulatory proteins. We represent a coregulated set (which may, or may not, be considered a regulon) using CoregulatedSet.

Field.name: source-id
Field.Notes: original ID of this coregulated set in the source (core) database

Field.name: binding-location
Field.Notes: binding location for this set's transcription factor; there may be none of these or there may be more than one

Entity.name: AtomicRegulon
Entity.Notes: An atomic regulon is an indivisible group of coregulated features on a single genome. Atomic regulons are constructed so that a given feature can only belong to one. Because of this, the expression levels for atomic regulons represent in some sense the state of a cell.
Entity.Asides:
An atomicRegulon is a set of protein-encoding genes that are believed to have identical expression profiles (i.e., they will all be expressed or none will be expressed in the vast majority of conditions). These are sometimes referred to as "atomic regulons". Note that there are more common notions of "coregulated set of genes" based on the notion that a single regulatory mechanism impacts an entire set of genes. Since multiple other mechanisms may impact overlapping sets, the genes impacted by a regulatory mechanism need not all share the same expression profile. We use a distinct notion (CoregulatedSet) to reference sets of genes impacted by a single regulatory mechanism (i.e., by a single transcription regulator).
The ID of an atomic regulon is the genome ID, a colon, and the atomic regulon sequence number.

Entity.name: Alignment
Entity.Notes: An alignment arranges a group of sequences so that they match. Each alignment is associated with a phylogenetic tree that describes how the sequences developed and their evolutionary distance.
Entity.Asides:
The Kbase will maintain a set of alignments and associated trees. The majority of these will be based on protein sequences. We will not have a comprehensive set, but we will have tens of thousands of such alignments, and we view them as an imporant resource to support annotation.
The alignments/trees will include data on the tools and parameters used to construct them.
Access to the underlying sequences and trees in a form convenient to existing tools will be supported.

Field.name: n-rows
Field.Notes: number of rows in the alignment

Field.name: n-cols
Field.Notes: number of columns in the alignment

Field.name: status
Field.Notes: status of the alignment, currently either [i]active[/i], [i]superseded[/i], or [i]bad[/i]

Field.name: is-concatenation
Field.Notes: TRUE if the rows of the alignment map to multiple sequences, FALSE if they map to single sequences

Field.name: sequence-type
Field.Notes: type of sequence being aligned, currently either [i]Protein[/i], [i]DNA[/i], [i]RNA[/i], or [i]Mixed[/i]

Field.name: timestamp
Field.Notes: date and time the alignment was loaded

Field.name: method
Field.Notes: name of the primary software package or script used to construct the alignment

Field.name: parameters
Field.Notes: non-default parameters used as input to the software package or script indicated in the method attribute

Field.name: protocol
Field.Notes: description of the steps taken to construct the alignment, or a reference to an external pipeline

Field.name: source-id
Field.Notes: ID of this alignment in the source database

Entity.name: AlignmentAttribute
Entity.Notes: This entity represents an attribute type that can be assigned to an alignment. The attribute values are stored in the relationships to the target. The key is the attribute name.

Entity.name: TreeNodeAttribute
Entity.Notes: This entity represents an attribute type that can be assigned to a node. The attribute values are stored in the relationships to the target. The key is the attribute name.

Entity.name: TreeAttribute
Entity.Notes: This entity represents an attribute type that can be assigned to a tree. The attribute values are stored in the relationships to the target. The key is the attribute name.

Entity.name: AlignmentRow
Entity.Notes: This entity represents a single row of an alignment. In general, this corresponds to a sequence, but in a concatenated alignment multiple sequences may be represented here.

Field.name: row-number
Field.Notes: 1-based ordinal number of this row in the alignment

Field.name: row-id
Field.Notes: identifier for this row in the FASTA file for the alignment

Field.name: row-description
Field.Notes: description of this row in the FASTA file for the alignment

Field.name: n-components
Field.Notes: number of components that make up this alignment row; for a single-sequence alignment this is always "1"

Field.name: beg-pos-aln
Field.Notes: the 1-based column index in the alignment where this sequence row begins

Field.name: end-pos-aln
Field.Notes: the 1-based column index in the alignment where this sequence row ends

Field.name: md5-of-ungapped-sequence
Field.Notes: the MD5 of this row's sequence after gaps have been removed; for DNA and RNA sequences, the [b]U[/b] codes are also normalized to [b]T[/b] before the MD5 is computed

Field.name: sequence
Field.Notes: sequence for this alignment row (with indels)

Entity.name: Tree
Entity.Notes: A tree describes how the sequences in an alignment relate to each other. Most trees are phylogenetic, but some may be based on taxonomy or gene content.

Field.name: status
Field.Notes: status of the tree, currently either [i]active[/i], [i]superseded[/i], or [i]bad[/i]

Field.name: data-type
Field.Notes: type of data the tree was built from, usually [i]sequence_alignment[/i]

Field.name: timestamp
Field.Notes: date and time the tree was loaded

Field.name: method
Field.Notes: name of the primary software package or script used to construct the tree

Field.name: parameters
Field.Notes: non-default parameters used as input to the software package or script indicated in the method attribute

Field.name: protocol
Field.Notes: description of the steps taken to construct the tree, or a reference to an external pipeline

Field.name: source-id
Field.Notes: ID of this tree in the source database

Field.name: newick
Field.Notes: NEWICK format string containing the structure of the tree

Entity.name: Strain
Entity.Notes: This entity represents an organism derived from a genome or another organism with one or more modifications to the organism's genome.

Field.name: name
Field.Notes: The common or laboratory name of the strain, e.g. DH5a or JMP1004.

Field.name: description
Field.Notes: A description of the strain, e.g. knockout/modification methods, resulting phenotypes, etc.

Field.name: source-id
Field.Notes: The ID of the strain used by the data source.

Field.name: aggregateData
Field.Notes: Denotes whether this entity represents a physical strain (False) or aggregate data calculated from one or more strains (True).

Field.name: wildtype
Field.Notes: Denotes this strain is presumably identical to the parent genome.

Field.name: referenceStrain
Field.Notes: Denotes whether this strain is a reference strain; e.g. it is identical to the genome it's related to (True) or not (False). In contrast to wildtype, a referenceStrain is abstract and does not physically exist and is used for data that refers to a genome but not a particular strain. There should only exist one reference strain per genome and all reference strains are wildtype.

Index.Notes: This index allows the user to search for a strain by source ID.
This index allows the user to search for a strain by whether it is a wildtype strain.
This index allows the user to search for a strain by whether it represents aggregate data.

Entity.name: ExperimentalUnit
Entity.Notes: An ExperimentalUnit is a subset of an experiment consisting of a Strain, an Environment, and one or more Measurements on that strain in the specified environment. ExperimentalUnits belong to a single experiment.

Field.name: source-id
Field.Notes: The ID of the experimental unit used by the data source.

Index.Notes: This index allows the user to search for a experimental unit by source ID.

Entity.name: ExperimentalUnitGroup
Entity.Notes: An ExperimentalUnitGroup allows for grouping related experimental units and their measurements - for instance measurements that were in the same plate.

Field.name: source-id
Field.Notes: The ID of the experimental unit group used by the data source.

Field.name: name
Field.Notes: The name of this group, if any.

Field.name: comments
Field.Notes: Any comments about this group.

Field.name: groupType
Field.Notes: The type of this grouping, for example '24 well plate', '96 well plate', '384 well plate', 'microarray'.

Index.Notes: This index allows the user to search for a experimental unit group by source ID.

Entity.name: TimeSeries
Entity.Notes: A TimeSeries provides a means to specify a series of experimental data over time by ordering multiple ExperimentalUnits.

Field.name: source-id
Field.Notes: The ID of the time series used by the data source.

Field.name: name
Field.Notes: The name of this time series, if any.

Field.name: comments
Field.Notes: Any comments regarding this time series.

Field.name: timeUnits
Field.Notes: The units of time for this time series, e.g. 'seconds', 'hours', or more abstractly, 'number of times culture grown to saturation.'

Index.Notes: This index allows the user to search for a time series by source ID.

Entity.name: Measurement
Entity.Notes: A Measurement is a value generated by performing a protocol to evaluate a value on an ExperimentalUnit - e.g. a strain in an environment.

Field.name: source-id
Field.Notes: The ID of the measurement used by the data source.

Field.name: value
Field.Notes: The value of the measurement.

Field.name: mean
Field.Notes: The mean of multiple replicates if they are included in the measurement.

Field.name: median
Field.Notes: The median of multiple replicates if they are included in the measurement.

Field.name: stddev
Field.Notes: The standard deviation of multiple replicates if they are included in the measurement.

Field.name: N
Field.Notes: The number of replicates if they are included in the measurement.

Field.name: p-value
Field.Notes: The p-value of multiple replicates if they are included in the measurement. The exact meaning of the p-value is specified in the MeasurementDescription object for this measurement.

Field.name: Z-score
Field.Notes: The Z-score of multiple replicates if they are included in the measurement. The exact meaning of the Z-score is specified in the MeasurementDescription object for this measurement.

Index.Notes: This index allows the user to search for a measurement by source ID.

Entity.name: MeasurementDescription
Entity.Notes: A MeasurementDescription provides information about a measurement value.

Field.name: name
Field.Notes: The name of the measurement.

Field.name: description
Field.Notes: The description of the measurement, how it is measured, and what the measurement statistics mean.

Field.name: unitOfMeasure
Field.Notes: The units of the measurement.

Field.name: category
Field.Notes: The category the measurement fits into, for example phenotype, experimental input, environment.

Field.name: source-id
Field.Notes: The ID of the measurement description used by the data source.

Index.Notes: This index allows the user to search for a measurement description by source ID.

Entity.name: ExperimentMeta
Entity.Notes: An Experiment consists of (potentially) multiple strains, environments, and measurements on those strains and environments.

Field.name: title
Field.Notes: Title of the experiment.

Field.name: description
Field.Notes: Description of the experiment including the experimental plan, general results, and conclusions, if possible.

Field.name: source-id
Field.Notes: The ID of the experiment used by the data source.

Field.name: startDate
Field.Notes: The date this experiment was started.

Field.name: comments
Field.Notes: Any data describing the experiment that is not covered by the description field.

Index.Notes: This index allows the user to search for a experiment meta object by source ID.

Entity.name: Person
Entity.Notes: A person represents a human affiliated in some way with Kbase.

Field.name: firstName
Field.Notes: The given name of the person.

Field.name: lastName
Field.Notes: The surname of the person.

Field.name: contactEmail
Field.Notes: Email address of the person.

Field.name: institution
Field.Notes: The institution where the person works.

Field.name: source-id
Field.Notes: The ID of the person used by the data source.

Index.Notes: This index allows the user to search for a person by source ID.
This index allows the user to search for a person by name.

Entity.name: Protocol
Entity.Notes: A Protocol is a step by step set of instructions for performing a part of an experiment.

Field.name: name
Field.Notes: The name of the protocol.

Field.name: description
Field.Notes: The step by step instructions for performing the experiment, including measurement details, materials, and equipment. A researcher should be able to reproduce the experimental results with this information.

Field.name: source-id
Field.Notes: The ID of the protocol used by the data source.

Index.Notes: This index allows the user to search for a protocol by source ID.

Entity.name: Environment
Entity.Notes: An Environment is a set of conditions for microbial growth, including temperature, aerobicity, media, and supplementary conditions.

Field.name: temperature
Field.Notes: The temperature in Kelvin.

Field.name: description
Field.Notes: A description of the environment.

Field.name: oxygenConcentration
Field.Notes: The oxygen concentration in the environment in Molar (mol/L). A value of -1 indicates that there is oxygen in the environment but the concentration is not known, (e.g. an open air shake flask experiment).

Field.name: pH
Field.Notes: The pH of the media used in the environment.

Field.name: source-id
Field.Notes: The ID of the environment used by the data source.

Index.Notes: This index allows the user to search for an environment by source ID.
This index allows the user to search for an environment by temperature.
This index allows the user to search for an environment by pH.
This index allows the user to search for an environment by oxygen concentration.

Entity.name: Parameter
Entity.Notes: A parameter is the name of some quantity that has a value.

Entity.name: RegulogCollection
Entity.Notes: A RegulogCollection describes a set of regulogs that are being curated on well-defined set of genomes.

Field.name: name
Field.Notes: The name of this regulog collection.

Field.name: description
Field.Notes: A brief description of this regulog collection.

Field.name: name
Field.Notes: Name of this effector.

Field.name: effector-class
Field.Notes: The class of this effector.

Field.name: description
Field.Notes: A short description for this regulon.

Field.name: description
Field.Notes: A short description for this regulome.

Field.name: creation-date
Field.Notes: Creation date for this regulome.

Field.name: name
Field.Notes: A human-readable name for this Regulator.

Field.name: rfam-id
Field.Notes: If this regulator is an RNA regulator, the rfam-id field will contain the RFAM identifier corresponding to it.

Field.name: tf-family
Field.Notes: If this regulator is a transcription factor, then the tf-family field will contain the name of the transcription factor family.

Field.name: type
Field.Notes: Type of the regulator; currently either RNA or TF.

Field.name: taxonomy
Field.Notes: Type of the regulator; currently either RNA or TF.

Entity.name: AssociationDataset
Entity.Notes: An Association Dataset is a collection of PPI data imported from a single database or publication.

Field.name: description
Field.Notes: This is a description of the dataset.

Field.name: data-source
Field.Notes: Optional external source for this dataset; e.g., another database.

Field.name: url
Field.Notes: Optional URL for more info about this dataset.

Field.name: association-type
Field.Notes: The type of this association.

Entity.name: Association
Entity.Notes: An Association represents a protein complex or a pairwise (binary) physical association between proteins.

Field.name: name
Field.Notes: This is the name of the association.

Field.name: description
Field.Notes: This is a description of this association. If the protein complex has a name, this should be it.

Field.name: directional
Field.Notes: True for directional binary associations (e.g., those detected by a pulldown experiment), false for non-directional binary associations and complexes. Bidirectional associations (e.g., associations detected by reciprocal pulldown experiments) should be encoded as 2 separate binary associations.

Field.name: confidence
Field.Notes: Optional numeric estimate of confidence in the association. Recommended to use a 0-100 scale.

Field.name: url
Field.Notes: Optional URL for more info about this complex.

Entity.name: AssociationDetectionType
Entity.Notes: This documents methods by which associations are detected or annotated.

Field.name: description
Field.Notes: This is a brief description of this detection method.

Entity.name: ConservedDomainModel
Entity.Notes:
A ConservedDomainModel represents a conserved domain model as found in the NCBI CDD archive.
The id of a ConservedDomainModel is the PSSM-Id.

Field.name: accession
Field.Notes: CD accession (starting with 'cd', 'pfam', 'smart', 'COG', 'PRK' or "CHL')

Field.name: short-name
Field.Notes: CD short name

Field.name: description
Field.Notes: CD description

Entity.name: Series
Entity.Notes: A series refers to a group of samples for expression data.
Entity.Asides: This often times will map to a GEO Series aka GSE#.

Field.name: title
Field.Notes: free text - title of the series

Field.name: summary
Field.Notes: free text - summary of the series

Field.name: design
Field.Notes: free text - design of the series

Field.name: externalSourceId
Field.Notes: The externalSourceId gives users potentially an easy way to find the data of interest (ex:GSE2365). This will keep them from having to do problematic likes on the source-id field.

Field.name: kbaseSubmissionDate
Field.Notes: date of submission (to Kbase)

Field.name: externalSourceDate
Field.Notes: date that may exist in the external source metadata (could be to GEO, M3D etc...)

Field.name: source-id
Field.Notes: The ID of the environment used by the data source.

Index.Notes: This index provides the ability to search by title. It should only be used for LIKE-style searches.
This index allows retrieval by the external source id.
This index allows retrieval by the source id.

Entity.name: Platform
Entity.Notes: Platform that the expression sample/experiment was run on.
Entity.Asides: This often times will map to a GEO Platform (aka GPL).

Field.name: title
Field.Notes: free text title of the comparison

Field.name: externalSourceId
Field.Notes: The externalSourceId gives users potentially an easy way to find the data of interest (ex:GPL514). This will keep them from having to do problematic likes on the source-id field.

Field.name: technology
Field.Notes: Ideally enumerated values, but may have to make this free text (spotted DNA/cDNA, spotted oligonucleotide, in situ oligonucleotide, antibody, tissue, SARST, RT-PCR, or MPSS).

Field.name: type
Field.Notes: Enumerated Microarray, RNA-Seq, qPCR

Field.name: source-id
Field.Notes: The ID used as the data source.

Index.Notes: This index allows retrieval by the external source id.
This index allows retrieval by the source id.

Entity.name: Sample
Entity.Notes: A sample is an experiment. In intensity experiment situations the sample will map 1 to 1 to the GSM. In this case there will be corresponding log2level data stored in the Measurement table.
Entity.Asides: This often times will map to a GEO GSM.

Field.name: title
Field.Notes: free text title of the sample

Field.name: dataSource
Field.Notes: The Data Source will be a way to identify where the data came from. Examples might be : GEO, SEED Expression Pipeline, Enigma, M3D

Field.name: externalSourceId
Field.Notes: The externalSourceId gives users potentially an easy way to find the data of interest (ex:GSM9514). This will keep them from having to do problematic likes on the source-id field.

Field.name: description
Field.Notes: Free-text descibing the experiment.

Field.name: molecule
Field.Notes: Enumerated field (total RNA, polyA RNA, cytoplasmic RNA, nuclear RNA, genomic DNA).

Field.name: type
Field.Notes: Enumerated Microarray, RNA-Seq, qPCR

Field.name: kbaseSubmissionDate
Field.Notes: date of submission to Kbase

Field.name: externalSourceDate
Field.Notes: date that may exist in the external source metadata (could be to GEO, M3D etc...)

Field.name: custom
Field.Notes: A flag to keep track if this series was generated by custom operations (averaging or comparison)

Field.name: originalLog2Median
Field.Notes: The Original Median of the sample in log2space. If null means the original median was not able to be determined.

Field.name: source-id
Field.Notes: The ID of the environment used by the data source.

Field.name: dataQualityLevel
Field.Notes: The quality of the data. Lower the number the better. Details need to be worked out.

Field.name: shock-url
Field.Notes: URL of the file location in Shock. Ex: the shock url for the RNA-Seq GTF file.

Field.name: processing-comments
Field.Notes: Processing comments. Examples how mapping was done. If representative CDS were used.

Field.name: numerical-interpretation
Field.Notes: The numerical space that the data is in. Examples : Log2 level intensities, Log2 level ratios, FPKM

Field.name: characteristics
Field.Notes: Free-text descibing the characteristics of the experiment (potentially for 1 or 2 channels).

Index.Notes: Allows for quick retrieval of certain molecule types.
This index allows retrieval by the source id.
Allows for quick retrieval of certain dataQualityLevels.
Allows for quick retrieval of numeric types.

Entity.name: Ontology
Entity.Notes: -- Environmental Ontology. (ENVO Terms) http://environmentontology.org/ -- Plant Ontology (PO Terms). http://www.plantontology.org/ -- Plant Environmental Ontology (EO Terms). http://www.gramene.org/plant_ontology/index.html#eo -- ENVO : http://envo.googlecode.com/svn/trunk/src/envo/envo-basic.obo -- PO : http://palea.cgrb.oregonstate.edu/viewsvn/Poc/tags/live/plant_ontology.obo?view=co -- EO : http://obo.cvs.sourceforge.net/viewvc/obo/obo/ontology/phenotype/environment/environment_ontology.obo

Field.name: id
Field.Notes: Ontologgy ID.

Field.name: name
Field.Notes: Type of the ontology.

Field.name: definition
Field.Notes: Definition of the ontology

Field.name: ontologySource
Field.Notes: Enumerated value (ENVO, EO, PO).

Entity.name: SampleAnnotation
Entity.Notes: Keeps track of ontology annotation date (and person if not automated).

Field.name: annotationDate
Field.Notes: date of annotation

Field.name: source-id
Field.Notes: The ID of the environment used by the data source.

Index.Notes: This index allows retrieval by the source id.

Entity.name: ReplicateGroup
Entity.Notes: Keeps track of Replicate Groups of Expression Samples. Has only an ID. Relationship is the important part.

Relationship.name: IsConservedDomainModelFor
Relationship.Notes: This relationship connects a protein sequence with the conserved domains that have been computed to be associated with it. Connections were determined using RPS-BLAST.

Field.name: percent-identity
Field.Notes: Percent identity over the length of the alignment.

Field.name: alignment-length
Field.Notes: Length of the aligned region.

Field.name: mismatches
Field.Notes: Number of mismatches in the alignment.

Field.name: gap-openings
Field.Notes: Number of gaps in the alignment.

Field.name: protein-start
Field.Notes: Alignment start on the protein.

Field.name: protein-end
Field.Notes: Alignment end on the protein.

Field.name: domain-start
Field.Notes: Alignment start on the CDD domain.

Field.name: domain-end
Field.Notes: Alignment end on the CDD domain.

Field.name: e-value
Field.Notes: The E-value is a parameter that describes the number of hits one can expect to see by chance when searching a database of a particular size. Essentially, the E-value describes the random background noise that exists for matches between sequences.

Field.name: bit-score
Field.Notes: The bit-score is derived from the raw alignment score S in which the statistical properties of the scoring system used have been taken into account. By normalizing a raw score, a [i]bit score[/i] is attained, which has a standard set of units.

Relationship.name: ImplementsReaction
Relationship.Notes: This relationship connects features to reaction instances that exist because the feature is included in a model.

Relationship.name: Treed
Relationship.Notes: This relationship connects a tree to the source database from which it was generated.

Relationship.name: UsesCodons
Relationship.Notes: This relationship connects a genome to the various codon usage records for it.

Relationship.name: IsModifiedToBuildTree
Relationship.Notes: Relates a tree to other trees built from it.

Field.name: modification-type
Field.Notes: description of how the tree was modified (rerooted, annotated, etc.)

Field.name: modification-value
Field.Notes: description of any parameters used to derive the modification

Relationship.name: IsModifiedToBuildAlignment
Relationship.Notes: Relates an alignment to other alignments built from it.

Field.name: modification-type
Field.Notes: description of how the alignment was modified

Field.name: modification-value
Field.Notes: description of any parameters used to derive the modification

Relationship.name: StrainParentOf
Relationship.Notes: The recursive StrainParentOf relationship organizes derived organisms into a tree based on parent/child relationships.

Relationship.name: GenomeParentOf
Relationship.Notes: The GenomeParentOf relationship specifies the direct child strains of a specific genome.

Relationship.name: HasKnockoutIn
Relationship.Notes: The HasKnockoutIn relationship specifies the gene knockouts in a particular strain.

Relationship.name: EvaluatedIn
Relationship.Notes: The EvaluatedIn relationship specifies the experimental units performed on a particular strain.

Relationship.name: HasMeasurement
Relationship.Notes: The HasMeasurement relationship specifies a measurement(s) performed on a particular experimental unit.

Relationship.name: DescribesMeasurement
Relationship.Notes: The DescribesMeasurement relationship specifies a description for a particular measurement.

Relationship.name: HasExperimentalUnit
Relationship.Notes: The HasExperimentalUnit relationship describes which ExperimentalUnits are part of a Experiment.

Relationship.name: PublishedExperiment
Relationship.Notes: The PublishedExperiment relationship describes where a particular experiment was published.

Relationship.name: IsMeasurementMethodOf
Relationship.Notes: The IsMeasurementMethodOf relationship describes which protocol was used to take a measurement.

Relationship.name: PublishedProtocol
Relationship.Notes: The ProtocolPublishedIn relationship describes where a particular protocol was published.

Relationship.name: IsContextOf
Relationship.Notes: The IsContextOf relationship describes the enviroment a subexperiment defined by an ExperimentalUnit was performed in.

Relationship.name: UsedIn
Relationship.Notes: The UsedIn relationship defines which media is used by an Environment.

Relationship.name: PerformedExperiment
Relationship.Notes: Denotes that a Person was associated with a Experiment in some role.

Field.name: role
Field.Notes: Describes the role the person played in the experiment. Examples are Primary Investigator, Designer, Experimentalist, etc.

Relationship.name: HasPresenceOf
Relationship.Notes: This relationship connects a media to the compounds that occur in it. The intersection data describes how much of each compound can be found.

Field.name: concentration
Field.Notes: The concentration of the compound in the media. A null value indicates that although the compound is present in the media, its concentration is not specified. This is typically the case for model medias which do not have physical analogs.

Field.name: minimum-flux
Field.Notes: minimum flux level for the compound in the medium.

Field.name: maximum-flux
Field.Notes: maximum flux level for the compound in the medium.

Relationship.name: IncludesAdditionalCompounds
Relationship.Notes: This relationship connects a environment to the compounds that occur in it. The intersection data describes how much of each compound can be found.

Field.name: concentration
Field.Notes: The concentration of the compound in the environment. A null value indicates that although the compound is present in the environment, its concentration is not specified. This is typically the case for model environments which do not have physical analogs.

Field.name: units
Field.Notes: vol%, g/L, or molar (mol/L).

Relationship.name: SupersedesAlignment
Relationship.Notes: This relationship connects an alignment to the alignments it replaces.

Field.name: successor-type
Field.Notes: Indicates whether sequences were removed or added to create the new alignment.

Relationship.name: SupersedesTree
Relationship.Notes: This relationship connects a tree to the trees it replaces.

Field.name: successor-type
Field.Notes: Indicates whether sequences were removed or added to create the new tree.

Relationship.name: IncludesAlignmentRow
Relationship.Notes: This relationship connects an alignment to its component rows.

Relationship.name: DescribesAlignment
Relationship.Notes: This relationship connects an alignment to its free-form attributes.

Field.name: value
Field.Notes: value of this attribute

Relationship.name: DescribesTree
Relationship.Notes: This relationship connects a tree to its free-form attributes.

Field.name: value
Field.Notes: value of this attribute

Relationship.name: DescribesTreeNode
Relationship.Notes: This relationship connects an tree to the free-form attributes of its nodes.

Field.name: value
Field.Notes: value of this attribute

Field.name: node-id
Field.Notes: ID of the node described by the attribute

Relationship.name: IsUsedToBuildTree
Relationship.Notes: This relationship connects each tree to the alignment from which it is built. There is at most one.

Relationship.name: ContainsAlignedProtein
Relationship.Notes: This relationship connects a protein alignment row to the protein sequences from which its components are formed.

Field.name: index-in-concatenation
Field.Notes: 1-based ordinal position in the alignment row of this protein sequence

Field.name: beg-pos-in-parent
Field.Notes: 1-based position in the protein sequence of the first amino acid that appears in the alignment

Field.name: end-pos-in-parent
Field.Notes: 1-based position in the protein sequence of the last amino acid that appears in the alignment

Field.name: parent-seq-len
Field.Notes: length of original sequence

Field.name: beg-pos-aln
Field.Notes: the 1-based column index in the alignment where this protein sequence begins

Field.name: end-pos-aln
Field.Notes: the 1-based column index in the alignment where this protein sequence ends

Field.name: kb-feature-id
Field.Notes: ID of the feature relevant to this protein, or an empty string if the protein is not specific to a genome

Relationship.name: ContainsAlignedDNA
Relationship.Notes: This relationship connects a nucleotide alignment row to the contig sequences from which its components are formed.

Field.name: index-in-concatenation
Field.Notes: 1-based ordinal position in the alignment row of this nucleotide sequence

Field.name: beg-pos-in-parent
Field.Notes: 1-based position in the contig sequence of the first nucleotide that appears in the alignment

Field.name: end-pos-in-parent
Field.Notes: 1-based position in the contig sequence of the last nucleotide that appears in the alignment

Field.name: parent-seq-len
Field.Notes: length of original sequence

Field.name: beg-pos-aln
Field.Notes: the 1-based column index in the alignment where this nucleotide sequence begins

Field.name: end-pos-aln
Field.Notes: the 1-based column index in the alignment where this nucleotide sequence ends

Field.name: kb-feature-id
Field.Notes: ID of the feature relevant to this sequence, or an empty string if the sequence is not specific to a genome

Relationship.name: Aligned
Relationship.Notes: This relationship connects an alignment to the database from which it was generated.

Relationship.name: HasVariationIn
Relationship.Notes: This relationship defines an observational unit's DNA variation from a contig in the reference genome.

Field.name: position
Field.Notes: Position of this variation in the reference contig.

Field.name: len
Field.Notes: Length of the variation in the reference contig. A length of zero indicates an insertion.

Field.name: data
Field.Notes: Replacement DNA for the variation on the primary chromosome. An empty string indicates a deletion. The primary chromosome is chosen arbitrarily among the two chromosomes of a plant's chromosome pair (one coming from the mother and one from the father).

Field.name: data2
Field.Notes: Replacement DNA for the variation on the secondary chromosome. This will frequently be the same as the primary chromosome string.

Field.name: quality
Field.Notes: Quality score assigned to this variation.

FromIndex.Notes: This index allows you to look for a variation by contig and position.

Relationship.name: HasTrait
Relationship.Notes: This relationship contains the measurement values of a trait on a specific observational Unit

Field.name: value
Field.Notes: value of the trait measurement

Field.name: statistic-type
Field.Notes: text description of the statistic type (e.g. mean, median)

Field.name: measure-id
Field.Notes: internal ID given to this measurement

Relationship.name: Impacts
Relationship.Notes: This relationship contains the best scoring statistical correlations between measured traits and the responsible alleles.

Field.name: source-name
Field.Notes: Name of the study which analyzed the data and determined that a variation has impact on a trait

Field.name: rank
Field.Notes: Rank of the position among all positions correlated with this trait.

Field.name: pvalue
Field.Notes: P-value of the correlation between the variation and the trait

Field.name: position
Field.Notes: Position in the reference contig where the trait has an impact.

ToIndex.Notes: This index allows you to look for trait impact by contig ID and position.

Relationship.name: IsAssayOf
Relationship.Notes: This relationship associates each assay with the relevant experiments.

Relationship.name: HasUnits
Relationship.Notes: This relationship associates observational units with the geographic location where the unit is planted.

Relationship.name: IncludesPart
Relationship.Notes: This relationship associates observational units with the experiments that generated the data on them.

Relationship.name: IsReferencedBy
Relationship.Notes: This relationship associates each observational unit with the reference genome that it will be compared to. All variations will be differences between the observational unit and the reference.

Relationship.name: IsRepresentedBy
Relationship.Notes: This relationship associates observational units with a genus, species, strain, and/or variety that was the source material.

Relationship.name: IsSummarizedBy
Relationship.Notes: This relationship describes the statistical frequencies of the most common alleles in various positions on the reference contig.

Field.name: position
Field.Notes: Position in the reference contig where the trait has an impact.

ToIndex.Notes: This index allows you to look for allelle frequency by contig ID and position.

Relationship.name: Formulated
Relationship.Notes: This relationship connects a coregulated set to the source organization that originally computed it.

Relationship.name: Involves
Relationship.Notes: This relationship connects a reaction to the specific localized compounds that participate in it.

Field.name: coefficient
Field.Notes: Number of molecules of the compound that participate in a single instance of the reaction. For example, if a reaction produces two water molecules, the stoichiometry of water for the reaction would be two. When a reaction is written on paper in chemical notation, the stoichiometry is the number next to the chemical formula of the compound. The value is negative for substrates and positive for products.

Field.name: cofactor
Field.Notes: TRUE if the compound is a cofactor; FALSE if it is a major component of the reaction.

Relationship.name: ParticipatesAs
Relationship.Notes: This relationship connects a generic compound to a specific compound where subceullar location has been specified.

Relationship.name: IsParticipatingAt
Relationship.Notes: This relationship connects a localized compound to the location in which it occurs during one or more reactions.

Relationship.name: ConsistsOfCompounds
Relationship.Notes: This relationship defines the subcompounds that make up a compound. For example, CoCl2-6H2O is made up of 1 Co2+, 2 Cl-, and 6 H2O.

Field.name: molar-ratio
Field.Notes: Number of molecules of the subcompound that make up the compound. A -1 in this field signifies that although the subcompound is present in the compound, the molar ratio is unknown.

Relationship.name: Controls
Relationship.Notes: This relationship connects a coregulated set to the features that are used as its transcription factors.

Relationship.name: Provided
Relationship.Notes: This relationship connects a source (core) database to the subsystems it submitted to the knowledge base.

Relationship.name: IsOwnerOf
Relationship.Notes: This relationship connects a genome to the features it contains. Though technically redundant (the information is available from the feature's contigs), it simplifies the extremely common process of finding all features for a genome.

Relationship.name: HasStep
Relationship.Notes: This relationship connects a complex to the reactions it catalyzes.

Relationship.name: Manages
Relationship.Notes: This relationship connects a model to its associated biomass composition reactions.

Relationship.name: IsComprisedOf
Relationship.Notes: This relationship connects a biomass composition reaction to the compounds specified as contained in the biomass.

Field.name: coefficient
Field.Notes: number of millimoles of the compound instance that exists in one gram cell dry weight of biomass

Relationship.name: HasUsage
Relationship.Notes: This relationship connects a specific compound in a model to the localized compound to which it corresponds.

Relationship.name: IsDividedInto
Relationship.Notes: This relationship connects a model to its instances of subcellular locations that participate in the model.

Relationship.name: IsInstantiatedBy
Relationship.Notes: This relationship connects a subcellular location to the instances of that location that occur in models.

Relationship.name: IsRealLocationOf
Relationship.Notes: This relationship connects a specific instance of a compound in a model to the specific instance of the model subcellular location where the compound exists.

Relationship.name: IsReagentIn
Relationship.Notes: This relationship connects a compound instance to the reaction instance in which it is transformed.

Field.name: coefficient
Field.Notes: Number of molecules of the compound that participate in a single instance of the reaction. For example, if a reaction produces two water molecules, the stoichiometry of water for the reaction would be two. When a reaction is written on paper in chemical notation, the stoichiometry is the number next to the chemical formula of the compound. The value is negative for substrates and positive for products.

Relationship.name: Submitted
Relationship.Notes: This relationship connects a genome to the core database from which it was loaded.

Relationship.name: IsComposedOf
Relationship.Notes: This relationship connects a genome to its constituent contigs. Unlike contig sequences, a contig belongs to only one genome.

Relationship.name: Encompasses
Relationship.Notes: This relationship connects a feature to a related feature; for example, it would connect a gene to its constituent splice variants, and the splice variants to their exons.

Relationship.name: IsSequenceOf
Relationship.Notes: This relationship connects a Contig as it occurs in a genome to the Contig Sequence that represents the physical DNA base pairs. A contig sequence may represent many contigs, but each contig has only one sequence.

Relationship.name: HasRequirementOf
Relationship.Notes: This relationship connects a model to the instances of reactions that represent how the reactions occur in the model.

Relationship.name: HasCompoundAliasFrom
Relationship.Notes: This relationship connects a source (database or organization) with the compounds for which it has assigned names (aliases). The alias itself is stored as intersection data.

Field.name: alias
Field.Notes: alias for the compound assigned by the source

FromIndex.Notes: This index can be used to look up a compound alias using the alias itself and the source.

Relationship.name: HasReactionAliasFrom
Relationship.Notes: This relationship connects a source (database or organization) with the reactions for which it has assigned names (aliases). The alias itself is stored as intersection data.

Field.name: alias
Field.Notes: alias for the reaction assigned by the source

FromIndex.Notes: This index can be used to look up a reaction alias using the alias itself and the source.

Relationship.name: IsTriggeredBy
Relationship.Notes: This connects a complex to the roles that work together to form the complex.

Field.name: optional
Field.Notes: TRUE if the role is not necessarily required to trigger the complex, else FALSE

Field.name: type
Field.Notes: a string code that is used to determine whether a complex should be added to a model

Field.name: triggering
Field.Notes: TRUE if the presence of the role requires including the complex in the model, else FALSE

Relationship.name: IsExemplarOf
