Relationship.Notes: This relationship links a role to a feature that provides a typical example of how the role is implemented.

Relationship.name: IsCoupledTo
Relationship.Notes: This relationship connects two FIGfams that we believe to be related either because their members occur in proximity on chromosomes or because the members are expressed together. Such a relationship is evidence the functions of the FIGfams are themselves related. This relationship is commutative; only the instance in which the first FIGfam has a lower ID than the second is stored.

Field.name: co-occurrence-evidence
Field.Notes: number of times members of the two FIGfams occur close to each other on chromosomes

Field.name: co-expression-evidence
Field.Notes: number of times members of the two FIGfams are co-expressed in expression data experiments

Relationship.name: HasRepresentativeOf
Relationship.Notes: This relationship connects a genome to the FIGfam protein families for which it has representative proteins. This information can be computed from other relationships, but it is provided explicitly to allow fast access to a genome's FIGfam profile.

Relationship.name: IndicatedLevelsFor
Relationship.Notes: This relationship connects a feature to a probe set from which experimental data was produced for the feature. It contains a vector of the expression levels.

Field.name: level-vector
Field.Notes: Vector of expression levels (-1, 0, 1) for the experiments, in sequence order.

Relationship.name: GeneratedLevelsFor
Relationship.Notes: This relationship connects an atomic regulon to a probe set from which experimental data was produced for its features. It contains a vector of the expression levels.

Field.name: level-vector
Field.Notes: Vector of expression levels (-1, 0, 1) for the experiments, in sequence order.

Relationship.name: ProducedResultsFor
Relationship.Notes: This relationship connects a probe set to a genome for which it was used to produce experimental results. In general, a probe set is used for only one genome and vice versa, but this is not a requirement.

Relationship.name: HasResultsIn
Relationship.Notes: This relationship connects a probe set to the experiments that were applied to it.

Field.name: sequence
Field.Notes: Sequence number of this experiment in the various result vectors.

ToIndex.Notes: This index allows you to access the experiments for a probe set in sequence order.

Relationship.name: AffectsLevelOf
Relationship.Notes: This relationship indicates the expression level of an atomic regulon for a given experiment.

Field.name: level
Field.Notes: Indication of whether the feature is expressed (1), not expressed (-1), or unknown (0).

Relationship.name: IsCoregulatedWith
Relationship.Notes: This relationship connects a feature with another feature in the same genome with which it appears to be coregulated as a result of expression data analysis.

Field.name: coefficient
Field.Notes: Pearson correlation coefficient for this coregulation.

Relationship.name: IsFormedOf
Relationship.Notes: This relationship connects each feature to the atomic regulon to which it belongs.

Relationship.name: IsConfiguredBy
Relationship.Notes: This relationship connects a genome to the atomic regulons that describe its state.

Relationship.name: HasIndicatedSignalFrom
Relationship.Notes: This relationship connects an experiment to a feature. The feature expression levels inferred from the experimental results are stored here.

Field.name: rma-value
Field.Notes: Normalized expression value for this feature under the experiment's conditions.

Field.name: level
Field.Notes: Indication of whether the feature is expressed (1), not expressed (-1), or unknown (0).

Relationship.name: HasValueFor
Relationship.Notes: This relationship connects an experiment to its attributes. The attribute values are stored here.

Field.name: value
Field.Notes: Value of this attribute in the given experiment. This is always encoded as a string, but may in fact be a number.

Relationship.name: OperatesIn
Relationship.Notes: This relationship connects an experiment to the media in which the experiment took place.

Relationship.name: IsRegulatedIn
Relationship.Notes: This relationship connects a feature to the set of coregulated features.

Relationship.name: IsFamilyFor
Relationship.Notes: This relationship connects an isofunctional family to the roles that make up its assigned function.

Relationship.name: IsConsistentWith
Relationship.Notes: This relationship connects a functional role to the EC numbers consistent with the chemistry described in the role.

Relationship.name: IsModeledBy
Relationship.Notes: A genome can be modeled by many different models, but a model belongs to only one genome.

Relationship.name: IsExecutedAs
Relationship.Notes: This relationship links a reaction to the way it is used in a model.

Relationship.name: IsTerminusFor
Relationship.Notes: A terminus for a scenario is a compound that acts as its input or output. A compound can be the terminus for many scenarios, and a scenario will have many termini. The relationship attributes indicate whether the compound is an input to the scenario or an output. In some cases, there may be multiple alternative output groups. This is also indicated by the attributes.

Field.name: group-number
Field.Notes: If zero, then the compound is an input. If one, the compound is an output. If two, the compound is an auxiliary output.

ToIndex.Notes: This index allows the application to view a scenario's compounds by group.

Relationship.name: IsSuperclassOf
Relationship.Notes: This is a recursive relationship that imposes a hierarchy on the subsystem classes.

Relationship.name: Describes
Relationship.Notes: This relationship connects a subsystem to the individual variants used to implement it. Each variant contains a slightly different subset of the roles in the parent subsystem.

Relationship.name: Displays
Relationship.Notes: This relationship connects a diagram to its reactions. A diagram shows multiple reactions, and a reaction can be on many diagrams.

Field.name: location
Field.Notes: Location of the reaction's node on the diagram.

Relationship.name: IsRelevantFor
Relationship.Notes: This relationship connects a diagram to the subsystems that are depicted on it. Only diagrams which are useful in curating or annotation the subsystem are specified in this relationship.

Relationship.name: IsImplementedBy
Relationship.Notes: This relationship connects a variant to the physical machines that implement it in the genomes. A variant is implemented by many machines, but a machine belongs to only one variant.

Relationship.name: Uses
Relationship.Notes: This relationship connects a genome to the machines that form its metabolic pathways. A genome can use many machines, but a machine is used by exactly one genome.

Relationship.name: Includes
Relationship.Notes: A subsystem is defined by its roles. The subsystem's variants contain slightly different sets of roles, but all of the roles in a variant must be connected to the parent subsystem by this relationship. A subsystem always has at least one role, and a role always belongs to at least one subsystem.

Field.name: sequence
Field.Notes: Sequence number of the role within the subsystem. When the roles are formed into a variant, they will generally appear in sequence order.

Field.name: abbreviation
Field.Notes: Abbreviation for this role in this subsystem. The abbreviations are used in columnar displays, and they also appear on diagrams.

Field.name: auxiliary
Field.Notes: TRUE if this is an auxiliary role, or FALSE if this role is a functioning part of the subsystem.

FromIndex.Notes: This index insures that the roles of the subsystem are presented in sequence order.

Relationship.name: IsFunctionalIn
Relationship.Notes: This relationship connects a role with the features in which it plays a functional part.
Relationship.Asides: In most cases, the functional assignment of a feature is also its role; however, some features implement multiple roles, and each individual role is connected by a separate instance of this relationship.

Relationship.name: Shows
Relationship.Notes: This relationship indicates that a compound appears on a particular diagram. The same compound can appear on many diagrams, and a diagram always contains many compounds.

Field.name: location
Field.Notes: Location of the compound's node on the diagram.

Relationship.name: IsRoleOf
Relationship.Notes: This relationship connects a role to the machine roles that represent its appearance in a molecular machine. A machine role has exactly one associated role, but a role may be represented by many machine roles.

Relationship.name: IsSubInstanceOf
Relationship.Notes: This relationship connects a scenario to its subsystem it validates. A scenario belongs to exactly one subsystem, but a subsystem may have multiple scenarios.

Relationship.name: Overlaps
Relationship.Notes: A Scenario overlaps a diagram when the diagram displays a portion of the reactions that make up the scenario. A scenario may overlap many diagrams, and a diagram may be include portions of many scenarios.

Relationship.name: HasParticipant
Relationship.Notes: A scenario consists of many participant reactions that convert the input compounds to output compounds. A single reaction may participate in many scenarios.

Field.name: type
Field.Notes: Indicates the type of participaton. If 0, the reaction is in the main pathway of the scenario. If 1, the reaction is necessary to make the model work but is not in the subsystem. If 2, the reaction is part of the subsystem but should not be included in the modelling process.

FromIndex.Notes: This index presents the reactions in the scenario in order from most important to least important.

Relationship.name: IsInPair
Relationship.Notes: A pairing contains exactly two protein sequences. A protein sequence can belong to multiple pairings. When going from a protein sequence to its pairings, they are presented in alphabetical order by sequence key.

Relationship.name: IsTaxonomyOf
Relationship.Notes: A genome is assigned to a particular point in the taxonomy tree, but not necessarily to a leaf node. In some cases, the exact species and strain is not available when inserting the genome, so it is placed at the lowest node that probably contains the actual genome.

Field.name: confidence
Field.Notes: Confidence in this assignment. Level 5 means there is an exact scientific name match. Level 4 means the taxonomy ID was provided directly and the name matches an alias. Level 3 means the taxonomy ID was provided directly and the name does not match an alias. Level 2 means no taxonomy ID was provided and an alias matched. Level 0 means the taxonomy ID was estimated during loading.

Relationship.name: IsRowOf
Relationship.Notes: This relationship connects a subsystem spreadsheet row to its constituent spreadsheet cells.

Relationship.name: IsClassFor
Relationship.Notes: This relationship connects each subsystem class with the subsystems that belong to it. A class can contain many subsystems, but a subsystem is only in one class. Some subsystems are not in any class, but this is usually a temporary condition.

Relationship.name: IsAnnotatedBy
Relationship.Notes: This relationship connects a feature to its annotations. A feature may have multiple annotations, but an annotation belongs to only one feature.

Relationship.name: HasAliasAssertedFrom
Relationship.Notes: A Source may assert aliases for features.

Field.name: alias
Field.Notes: text of the alias for the feature.

Index.Notes: This index support searching by alias name.

Relationship.name: HasMember
Relationship.Notes: This relationship connects each feature family to its constituent features. A family always has many features, and a single feature can be found in many families.

Relationship.name: HasProteinMember
Relationship.Notes: This relationship connects each feature family to its constituent protein sequences. A family always has many protein sequences, and a single sequence can be found in many families.

Field.name: source-id
Field.Notes: Native identifier used for the protein in the definition of the family. This will be its ID in the alignment, if one exists.

FromIndex.Notes: This index orders the proteins in a family by their source ID.

Relationship.name: Concerns
Relationship.Notes: This relationship connects a publication to the protein sequences it describes.

Relationship.name: IsCollectionOf
Relationship.Notes: A genome belongs to only one genome set. For each set, this relationship marks the genome to be used as its representative.

Field.name: representative
Field.Notes: TRUE for the representative genome of the set, else FALSE.

Relationship.name: AssertsFunctionFor
Relationship.Notes: Sources (users) can make assertions about protein sequence function. The assertion is associated with an external identifier.

Field.name: function
Field.Notes: text of the assertion made about the identifier. It may be an empty string, indicating the function is unknown.

Field.name: external-id
Field.Notes: external identifier used in making the assertion

Field.name: organism
Field.Notes: organism name associated with this assertion. If the assertion is not associated with a specific organism, this will be an empty string.

Field.name: gi-number
Field.Notes: NCBI GI number associated with the asserted identifier

Field.name: release-date
Field.Notes: date and time the assertion was downloaded

Index.Notes: This index supports finding proteins by GI number.
This index supports finding proteins by external identifier.

Relationship.name: IsDeterminedBy
Relationship.Notes: A functional coupling evidence set exists because it has pairings in it, and this relationship connects the evidence set to its constituent pairings. A pairing cam belong to multiple evidence sets.

Field.name: inverted
Field.Notes: A pairing is an unordered pair of protein sequences, but its similarity to other pairings in a pair set is ordered. Let (A,B) be a pairing and (X,Y) be another pairing in the same set. If this flag is FALSE, then (A =~ X) and (B =~ Y). If this flag is TRUE, then (A =~ Y) and (B =~ X).

Relationship.name: Contains
Relationship.Notes: This relationship connects a subsystem spreadsheet cell to the features that occur in it. A feature may occur in many machine roles and a machine role may contain many features. The subsystem annotation process is essentially the maintenance of this relationship.

Relationship.name: IsProteinFor
Relationship.Notes: This relationship connects a peg feature to the protein sequence it produces (if any). Only peg features participate in this relationship. A single protein sequence will frequently be produced by many features.

Relationship.name: IsLocatedIn
Relationship.Notes: A feature is a set of DNA sequence fragments, the location of which are specified by the fields of this relationship. Most features are a single contiguous fragment, so they are located in only one DNA sequence; however, for search optimization reasons, fragments have a maximum length, so even a single contiguous feature may participate in this relationship multiple times. Thus, it is better to use the CDMI API methods to get feature positions and sequences as those methods rejoin the fragements for contiguous features. A few features belong to multiple DNA sequences. In that case, however, all the DNA sequences belong to the same genome. A DNA sequence itself will frequently have thousands of features connected to it.

Field.name: ordinal
Field.Notes: Sequence number of this segment, starting from 0 and proceeding sequentially forward from there.

Field.name: begin
Field.Notes: Index (1-based) of the first residue in the contig that belongs to the segment.
Field.Asides: The begin value is not the start residue, it is the leftmost residue. If the direction is backward, it will actually be the end residue.

Field.name: len
Field.Notes: Length of this segment.

Field.name: dir
Field.Notes: Direction (strand) of the segment: "+" if it is forward and "-" if it is backward.

FromIndex.Notes: This index allows the application to find all the segments of a feature in the proper order.

ToIndex.Notes: This index is the one used by applications to find all the feature segments that contain a specific residue.

Relationship.name: HasSection
Relationship.Notes: This relationship connects a contig's sequence to its DNA sequences.

Relationship.name: HasSection
Relationship.Notes: This relationship connects a contig's sequence to its DNA sequences.

Relationship.name: IsGroupFor
Relationship.Notes: The recursive IsGroupFor relationship organizes taxonomic groupings into a hierarchy based on the standard organism taxonomy.

Relationship.name: ContainsExperimentalUnit
Relationship.Notes: Experimental units may be collected into groups, such as assay plates. This relationship describes which experimenal units belong to which groups.

Field.name: location
Field.Notes: The location, if any, of the experimental unit in the group. Often a plate locator, e.g. 'G11' for 96 well plates.

Field.name: groupMeta
Field.Notes: Denotes that the associated ExperimentalUnit's data measures the group as a whole - for example, summary statistics.

Relationship.name: OrdersExperimentalUnit
Relationship.Notes: Experimental units may be ordered into time series. This relationship describes which experimenal units belong to which time series.

Field.name: time
Field.Notes: The time at which the associated ExperimentUnit's data was taken.

Field.name: timeMeta
Field.Notes: Denotes that the associated ExperimentalUnit's data measures the time series as a whole - for example, lag and doubling times for bacterial growth curves.

Relationship.name: CompoundMeasuredBy
Relationship.Notes: Denotes the compound that a measurement quantifies.

Relationship.name: FeatureMeasuredBy
Relationship.Notes: Denotes the feature that a measurement quantifies.

Relationship.name: HasParameter
Relationship.Notes: This relationship denotes which parameters each environment has, as well as the value of the parameter.

Field.name: value
Field.Notes: The value of the parameter.

Field.name: rank
Field.Notes: The rank (order) of this feature in the operon.

Relationship.name: IsDatasetFor
Relationship.Notes: The IsDatasetFor relationship describes which genomes are covered by particular association datasets.

Relationship.name: IsGroupingOf
Relationship.Notes: The IsGroupingOf relationship describes which associations are part of a particular association dataset.

Relationship.name: DetectedWithMethod
Relationship.Notes: The DetectedWithMethod relationship describes which protein-protein associations were detected or annotated by particular methods

Relationship.name: PublishedAssociation
Relationship.Notes: The PublishedAssociation relationship links associations to the manuscript they are published in.

Relationship.name: AssociationFeature
Relationship.Notes: The AssociationFeature relationship links associations to the features that encode their component proteins.

Field.name: stoichiometry
Field.Notes: Stoichiometry, if applicable (e.g., for a curated complex.

Field.name: strength
Field.Notes: Optional numeric measure of strength of the association (e.g., kD or relative estimate of binding affinity)

Field.name: rank
Field.Notes: Numbered starting at 1 within an Association, if directional. Meaning is method-dependent; e.g., for associations derived from pulldown data, rank 1 should be assigned to the bait. A rank of 0 indicates that there are no ordered relationships.

Relationship.name: SeriesPublishedIn
Relationship.Notes: This relationship indicates where the series was published.

Relationship.name: SampleContactPerson
Relationship.Notes: The people that performed the expression experiment(sample).

Relationship.name: StrainWithSample
Relationship.Notes: This indicates which expression samples a strain has.

Relationship.name: SampleInSeries
Relationship.Notes: This relationship indicates what samples are in a series. Note a sample can be in more than one series.

Relationship.name: StrainWithPlatforms
Relationship.Notes: This relationship indicates the platforms for a strain.

Relationship.name: PlatformWithSamples
Relationship.Notes: This relationship indicates the expression samples that were run on a particular platform.

Relationship.name: SampleMeasurements
Relationship.Notes: The Measurements for expression microarray data should be in Log2 space and the measurements for a given sample should have the median set to zero. RNA-Seq data will likely be in FPKM.

Relationship.name: PersonAnnotatedSample
Relationship.Notes: Only stores a person if a person annotates the data by hand. Automated Sample Annotations will not be annotated by a person.

Relationship.name: SampleHasAnnotations
Relationship.Notes: This relationship indicates the sample annotations that belong to the sample.

Relationship.name: ProtocolForSample
Relationship.Notes: This relationship indicates the protocol used in the expression sample.

Relationship.name: SampleAveragedFrom
Relationship.Notes: Custom averaging of samples (typically replicates).

Relationship.name: DefaultControlSample
Relationship.Notes: The Default control for samples to compare against. (Log2 measurments of Test Sample)/(Log2 measurements of Default Control). Really minus instead of divide since the values are already in Log2 Space.

Relationship.name: SamplesInReplicateGroup
Relationship.Notes: The samples that are identified as being part of one replicate group. All samples in replicate group are replicates of one another.

Relationship.name: OntologyForSample
Relationship.Notes: This relationship the ontology PO#, EO# or ENVO# associatioed with the sample.

Relationship.name: HasExpressionSample
Relationship.Notes: This relationship indicating the expression samples for an experimental unit.

Shape.name: BelongsToVariant
Shape.Notes: This relationship is not physically implemented in the database. It is implicit in the data for a variant. A variant contains a boolean expression that describes the various combinations of roles it can contain.
